intro: Panicum dichotomum var. acuminatum, commonly known as the narrowleaf panicgrass, is a grass species native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow, linear leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, spikelet-based inflorescences with pale green to brownish flowers, which are typically wind-pollinated. It thrives in well-drained soils and is drought-tolerant, making it a common species in disturbed or sandy habitats. Its morphology reflects adaptations to harsh environmental conditions, including reduced leaf surface area to minimize water loss.
